$description: Core line height primitives as percentage values. Percentage values scale proportionally with font size (150% = 1.5x font-size). ACCESSIBILITY: WCAG 1.4.12 requires line-height of at least 150% for body text. Tighter values (xs, sm) only for headings and single-line elements.

lineHeights.$description: Line height scale from tight (display) to loose (prose). Match line height to content type: tighter for headings, looser for body text. RULE: Longer line lengths need more line height. Use xs-sm only for headings/buttons, md-xl for readable content.

xs.$description: Tight line height (120%). Use for: large display headings, hero text, single-line elements, buttons, badges. Text appears compact and impactful. CAUTION: Not accessible for multi-line body text. Only use for headings 24px+ or single-line UI elements. Common in: h1, hero headlines, button text, badge labels.

sm.$description: Snug line height (135%). Use for: smaller headings (h3-h6), subheadings, short multi-line text, compact interfaces. Tighter than body but readable for short passages. Common in: h3-h6 headings, card titles, navigation items, form labels, compact UI text.

md.$description: Normal line height (150%). WCAG MINIMUM for body text. Use for: standard body text, paragraphs, UI descriptions, form inputs, most readable content. Baseline for accessibility compliance. Common in: body paragraphs, descriptions, form values, help text, table cells.

lg.$description: Relaxed line height (165%). Use for: longer paragraphs, improved readability, wide content areas, users who need more visual separation. Better for sustained reading. Common in: article content, documentation, expanded descriptions, accessibility-focused interfaces.

xl.$description: Loose line height (180%). Use for: long-form prose, documentation, maximum readability, accessibility accommodations. Very generous spacing between lines. Common in: blog posts, help documentation, legal text, content prioritizing readability over density.
